Subject: RE: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT Tutorial?

------=_NextPart_000_071B_01CA6E55.226880B0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

For what it's worth ...
 
I've found the ideas of wikis are better in concept than they ultimately
turn out to be when it comes to rapidly changing, emerging technologies. In
my opinion, there needs to be a forum to hash out concepts, many that will
turn out to be wrong, or only partially correct, or that eventually lead to
greater understanding - before they are committed to writing, either on a
wiki board or paper. Wrong paths are easily followed. I found small (< 50
participants) interactive webcasts good for this, in conjunction with
periodic conferences and rigorous publications.
 
HyperNEAT is a very rich and promising "concept seed" for the scientific
study of many things - not to mention what it teaches us about complex
systems, neuro-evolution and neuro-computation, artificial intelligence and
artificial cognitive capability.
 
So, would the tutorial focus on the internal workings of HyperNEAT and
genetically-inspired neuro-computation, or its application to various
problem domains?
 
Ken Lloyd
 



  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Ken
Sent: Wednesday, November 25, 2009 9:47 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT Tutorial?


  



Evert, the wiki idea is interesting. How do you see that working? Would it
be a place for the general public to post advice and information? 

I am talking to my group now about tutorial ideas and hopefully we will be
able to provide something along those lines. Of course there are a lot of
publication pressures for us at the same time, but we do recognize how
helpful it would be to users and we want to make using HyperNEAT easy. I
hope we will be able to provide something along these lines in the near
future.

ken 

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "Daniel"
<daniel_kuppitz@...> wrote:
>
> Hello Evert,
> 
> great idea. A wiki won't cover all the things a HOL can cover, but I agree
that it would be the best choice for any detailed parameter explanation. My
only concern is, that a wiki will also become very technical over time and
consequently scare away most of the new interested users (I always refer to
people like me, who consider neural networks only as a spare-time activity).
> 
> Cheers,
> Daniel
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, Evert
Haasdijk <evert@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi all,
> > 
> > Maybe a wiki would be just the ticket here?
> > 
> > Cheers,
> > 
> > Evert
> > 
> > 
> > On 23 Nov 2009, at 00:07, dkuppitz wrote:
> > 
> > > Hello Ken,
> > >
> > > here's just another vote for a tutorial, with the difference that I 
> > > would prefer it for HyperSharpNEAT.
> > >
> > > It would be great to see something like a HOL (Hands on Labs) where 
> > > a new experiment is created from the scratch. Parameters should be 
> > > explained in detail, for example: Which impact has the parameter 
> > > Treshold, which impact has WeightRange, etc.? How are the values for 
> > > each parameter determined, what is taken into account when you set 
> > > the values? There are so many unanswered questions for those who are 
> > > new to HyperNEAT and I think most people (including me) have a 
> > > really great interest in this topic, but not the time to read (and 
> > > understand) all the technical papers. So any tutorial should target 
> > > beginners and explain things that have become self-evident for 
> > > intermediates.
> > >
> > > I think one such "official" tutorial that explains every step in 
> > > detail should be enough, more will surely follow from the growing 
> > > community.
> > >
> > > Cheers,
> > > Daniel
> > >
> > > --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "Ken"
<kstanley@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Andrei, which version of HyperNEAT are you interested in and what 
> > > references have you looked at so far? We can potentially improve the 
> > > documentation based on your comments (and a tutorial is a good 
> > > idea), but first I want to understand which "comment-less examples" 
> > > you are referring to.
> > > >
> > > > Note that several experiments with complete source code are 
> > > available in two existing HyperNEAT releases of which I am aware. 
> > > These and a variety of publications from several groups are linked 
> > > from the HyperNEAT Users Page, which also provides a brief 
> > > introduction:
> > > >
> > > > http://eplex. <http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html>
cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html
> > > >
> > > > I understand you may have already been through this site and its 
> > > associated software and papers, but I wanted to point it out in case 
> > > you had not been aware of it.
> > > >
> > > > We want to make the algorithm as accessible as possible so your 
> > > comments are appreciated.
> > > >
> > > > ken
> > > >
> > > > --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com,
"Andrei" <andrei.rusu@> wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > Can anyone please recommend some HyperNEAT documentation, a 
> > > tutorial, diagram, some clue, or anything that does not mean reverse 
> > > engineering the comment-less examples ?
> > > > >
> > > > > Thanks! Andrei.
> > > > >
> > > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >
>
